# Sir Syed Global Scholar Award

}}
The Sir Syed Global Scholar Award (SSGSA) is an academic support initiative founded in 2006 to assist students and alumni of Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) in pursuing higher education abroad. Administered by the Sir Syed Education Society of North America, a U.S.-based nonprofit organization, the program provides mentorship and limited financial assistance.
History and development
The program was originally launched as the "Sir Syed Excellence in Science Award" in 2006 with the aim of facilitating access to graduate programs in the United States for AMU students. It was later renamed to reflect an expanded international scope.
Awardees receive support for graduate school applications, including funding for standardized test registration and application fees. They are also matched with volunteer mentors—often AMU alumni working in academia or industry—who guide them through the university application process. Over the years, the initiative has grown to include a broader set of disciplines and target destinations, including universities in Europe, Canada, and Asia.
Impact
As of 2025, the program has supported over 200 awardees in securing admission to universities in more than 20 countries. In 2020, during SSGSA’s annual convention, Nobel Laureate in Economics Abhijit Banerjee commended the organization as “a very noble enterprise and one that has great potential for transforming the lives of many people.”
Several alumni of the program have subsequently received competitive research fellowships and academic distinctions in both the United States and Europe. Alumni have also contributed to major international collaborations, including teams at CERN that were recognized with the 2025 Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics, as well as collaborations with LIGO, the IceCube Neutrino Observatory, and NASA’s Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe. An alumnus co-authored a 2025 study by the University of Texas at Austin, which modeled how early Martian surface water migrated into deep aquifers. Another alumnus contributed to research at the University of California, Davis and Berkeley Lab, developing a laser-based purification technique for silica to create ultra-pure glass for advanced electronic and optical applications. Other alumni contribute to major research projects at leading national laboratories such as the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, Argonne National Laboratory, Fermilab, and the SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory.
The organization has also collaborated with several U.S. universities to host Indian students for short-term summer research internships. These experiences have allowed participants to gain exposure to academic research environments abroad.
Community engagement
Award recipients often remain involved in the program after completing their studies. Many participate in peer mentoring, educational outreach, and nonprofit efforts to expand access to international education opportunities for underrepresented groups. This community-driven model has helped sustain a long-term network of support and guidance.
Media coverage
The initiative has received coverage in both Indian and international media for promoting academic mobility among minority and underrepresented students. A 2013 article in Business Standard highlighted its early collaborations with U.S. institutions that hosted AMU students for summer research internships. The Higher Education Review also reported on these partnerships.
Each year, announcements of the SSGSA awards are covered by Indian media outlets including the Hindustan Times, Ummid News, and Salam-e-Vatan.
